profiles:
Summary Research scientist with a broad background in management and problem solving within multiple scientific fields. Affable liaison between disparate teams. Adept at designing and leading programs, procuring resources and personnel to achieve strategic goals using minimal starting data.  
 
Extensive experience in structured problem solving, writing technical whitepapers, securing peer-reviewed grants, and communicating complex information in clear, easy-to-understand terminology to a lay audience. Execution oriented and able to deliver on projects that scale from startups to multi-institution organizations Summary Research scientist with a broad background in management and problem solving within multiple scientific fields. Affable liaison between disparate teams. Adept at designing and leading programs, procuring resources and personnel to achieve strategic goals using minimal starting data.

Affable liaison between disparate teams. Adept at designing and leading programs, procuring resources and personnel to achieve strategic goals using minimal starting data.  
 
Extensive experience in structured problem solving, writing technical whitepapers, securing peer-reviewed grants, and communicating complex information in clear, easy-to-understand terminology to a lay audience. Execution oriented and able to deliver on projects that scale from startups to multi-institution organizations Experience Program Officer/Senior Scientist; OB/GYN, Division of Gynecological Oncology Stanford University School of Medicine September 2014  – Present (1 year) Stanford, CA Develops, evaluates and implements basic and translational research programs. Identifies new funding opportunities to support research and educational missions of the Division of Gynecologic Oncology, with a focus on ovarian cancer. Works closely with division faculty and fellows to write and submit proposals. Scientific liaison to funding agencies as well as collaborating faculty at Stanford and at other institutions and companies. Sole Proprietor Schaar Medical Writing January 2013  – Present (2 years 8 months) Advises clients on how to clearly communicate their goals and align their proposals with funders’ portfolios. Created marketing strategies that leverage social media, web, and print collateral, which targeted potential donors and investors. Wrote copy and provided content management for white papers. 
 
•	Guided staff at the Synthetic Biology Engineering Research Center, a UC Berkeley-based multi-institutional center (Stanford, UCSF, UC Berkeley, Harvard and MIT), on web content and messaging for their Synthetic Biology Leadership Excellence Accelerator Program (LEAP). 
 
•	Worked as a subject matter expert (SME) with the Stanford University Medical Center’s Director of Marketing and Media to write copy for the Stanford Biomedical Innovation Initiative’s white paper. 
 
•	Consulted for Stanford BioDesign startups on their NSF and NIH Small Business Innovation (SBIR) grants. This included targeting the most relevant program, liaising between clients and program officers, checking the logic and messaging of the grant proposal and verifying the budget and milestones. Senior Scientist, Department of Developmental Biology Stanford University School of Medicine 2009  –  September 2012  (3 years) Lead the design, execution, and interpretation of wet lab experiments to test hypotheses generated from data mining of next generation sequencing. Provided scientific guidance and ensure deliverables are met; and coordinate with multi-disciplinary groups. Collaborative effort between the Department of Developmental Biology at Stanford School of Medicine and the School of Engineering. Recruited, trained, mentored three direct reports.  
 
•	Spearheaded start-up of wet lab with $500K in funding. Purchased equipment that set direction for 5-year course and complemented current facilities.  
 
•	Designed research plan to position department for $2 million National Health Institute (NIH) grant application. Met with NIH program directors to facilitate alignment of research with funding portfolios. 
 
•	Contributed to five manuscripts published in 2010-2012 (including papers in Nature and Nature Biotechnology), with three more to be published in 2013. Senior Scientist / Scientific Editor Stanford University School of Medicine, Department of Neurosurgery 2006  –  2009  (3 years) Guided faculty and students through the manuscript and grant writing process. Edited manuscripts for scientific content for submission to journals. Wrote and edited grant applications for the NIH and the California Institute for Regenerative Medicine. Compiled and submitted progress reports for NIH funding. Wrote copy for promotional brochures to explain research to lay audience. 
 
•	Secured $2 million NIH grant to study stem cell therapy for stroke recovery at time when less than 10% of grant applications were being funded. Established alliance with Molecular and Cellular Physiology Departments. 
 
•	Drove organization and writing of $20 million multi-component, multiple investigator grant from the California Institute for Regenerative Medicine with goal of bringing stem cell therapy for stroke recovery to FDA filing within four years. 
 
•	Developed copy for a magazine showcasing basic departmental research and Stanford’s pioneering neurosurgical techniques. Circulated to all U.S. neurosurgeons and major donors Life Science Research Associate, Department of Biological Sciences Stanford University 2003  –  2006  (3 years) Designed and performed basic research on mechanisms of mammalian brain development. Published work, and mentored graduate and undergraduate students. Presented work at conferences. 
 
•	Collaborated with human geneticists to understand how genetic lesions affected brain development. Received partial funding by the Human Frontiers Foundation. 
 
•	Published first author paper in Neuron, a top tier neuroscience journal. Featured on cover and was subject of review. Postdoctoral Fellow Stanford University 1998  –  2003  (5 years) Developed a new perspective for the field of neural development on the mechanisms of cell division and migration of newly born cortical neurons during mammalian brain development. 
 
Supported by an American Cancer Society Postdoctoral fellowship, Human Frontiers Science Program and the National Institute for Mental Health (NIMH). Graduate Student University of Pennsylvania 1991  –  1997  (6 years) Fox Chase Cancer Center Characterized the kinetochore component, CENP-E, which was eventually targeted by a putative chemotherapeutic agent, GSK-923295. Summary University and private foundation program officer with twenty-eight years of national experience in science policy and systemic education reform. Program team member developing new initiatives and awarding $20 M in grants annually for Education, Science, Technology, and the Economy at Carnegie Corporation of New York. Twenty years of academic program leadership at Stanford University working with interdisciplinary faculty teams across the university, managing major science education and technology initiatives, and developing competitive faculty grants programs. Extensive non-profit board of director experience focused on programs, governance, organizational leadership, and strategic planning. Experience National Board of Directors, Vice Chair for Education NatureBridge May 2004  – Present (11 years 4 months) NatureBridge provides residential environmental field science programs to students and teachers, in partnership with the National Park Service. Campuses are located in Yosemite, Olympic National Park, the Golden Gate National Recreational Area, Santa Monica Mountains, Channel Islands, and Prince William Forest in Virginia. Serve on the Executive Committee and as the Board Liaison to the expert Education Advisory Council. Also serve on the strategic plan task force and previously on the CEO search committee, governance task force, and nominations committee. Senior Academic and Research Program Officer Stanford University October 1990  –  September 2010  (20 years) Stanford University Executive Director of multi-year science education projects within the Program in Human Biology, funded by the National Science Foundation, National Institutes of Health, Carnegie Corporation of New York, and The David and Lucile Packard Foundation. Executive Director of the Wallenberg Global Learning Network, which supported $5.0M in competitive faculty grants for joint projects between Swedish Universities and Stanford University. Executive Director of the Initiative on Improving K-12 Education, part of The Stanford Challenge, with $2.0 M for interdisciplinary faculty grants awarded annually. Also served as a Lecturer in the School of Education, Co-teaching a graduate course on the History of Curriculum Reform in the United States. Board of Directors Biological Sciences Curriculum Study - BSCS 2004  –  2009  (5 years) Colorado Springs, Colorado Member of the Board of Directors overseeing the mission and core work of BSCS. Served as a member of the CEO search committee in 2007. Program Officer Carnegie Corporation of New York 1984  –  1990  (6 years) New York, New York Program on Education: Science, Technology, and the Economy. A member of the program grants team focused on improving science education and supporting key, systemic education and economic reform efforts in the United States following the publication of A Nation at Risk in 1983. Summary Annika Kahn is the founder of Jungshin Fitness 
She is a lifelong athlete and a 4-time world grand champion in the Korean Art of Kuk Sool Won, achieving the rank of 4th degree black belt. Her Jungshin Fitness workout has been featured on ABC, NBC, and in SHAPE, Martha Stewart's Whole Living, and Prevention magazines. She is a national presenter and develops programs that apply to youth, adults, and seniors. Annika offers instructor training's worldwide as well as education and corporate seminars on the connection between mental health and movement. Annika brings 20 years of experience in both eastern and western modalities of fitness to instructors, students, and fitness clubs in fun and inspiring ways. She holds a masters degree in the Psychology of Movement and integrates her passion and studies of molecular biology, physics, and mind/body movement into a cohesive and easily accessible format for all ages. Annika currently lives in San Francisco, California. 
_________________________________________________________________________________ 
MA -Post graduate studies and thesis with Ph.D Mathematician and Evolutionist,Dr. Brian Swimme

2014 workshops include; IoM with Michol Dalcourt and Thomas Myers, Paul Chek-Level 1, Jungshin Rhythm-Stanford University. 
World IDEA, SCW, and ACSM presenter 
 
Specialties: 4-time World Grand Champion, National Presenter (IDEA, SCW), credentialed - Mathematics and Science, national champion -Rowing, Certified Fitness Expert, launching authentic cutting-edge movement programs world-wide. Summary Annika Kahn is the founder of Jungshin Fitness 
She is a lifelong athlete and a 4-time world grand champion in the Korean Art of Kuk Sool Won, achieving the rank of 4th degree black belt. Her Jungshin Fitness workout has been featured on ABC, NBC, and in SHAPE, Martha Stewart's Whole Living, and Prevention magazines. She is a national presenter and develops programs that apply to youth, adults, and seniors. Annika offers instructor training's worldwide as well as education and corporate seminars on the connection between mental health and movement. Annika brings 20 years of experience in both eastern and western modalities of fitness to instructors, students, and fitness clubs in fun and inspiring ways. She holds a masters degree in the Psychology of Movement and integrates her passion and studies of molecular biology, physics, and mind/body movement into a cohesive and easily accessible format for all ages. Annika currently lives in San Francisco, California. 
_________________________________________________________________________________

CORPORATE EVENT FACILITATOR / TEAM BUILDING Jungshin Fitness February 2010  – Present (5 years 7 months) Jungshin Fitness offers Team Building Activities to Corporations using offensive and defensive games with swords to help management and employees learn to watch how their colleagues move in relationship to one-another, project proposals, group dynamics.
